docs.snippet: Roethlisberger threw for 300 yards and three touchdowns, including two to Antonio Brown. DeAngelo Williams rushed for 143 yards and two touchdowns....

docs.snippet: Pro athletes in today’s branded age have tended toward self-censorship on divisive issues. Kaepernick’s recent protests may be changing that....
docs.lead_paragraph: Pro athletes in today’s branded age have tended toward self-censorship on divisive issues. Kaepernick’s recent protests may be changing that.
docs.abstract: Protest by San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick is rare in professional sports and bears comparison to activism by earlier athletes like late heavyweight boxing champion Muhammad Ali, who refused to serve in Vietnam War;  professional athletes today risk losing endorsements, industry respect and potentially their careers through such protests, but despite risks some are joining Kaepernick and his stand against racial inequality and police brutality.

headline.main: As Colin Kaepernick’s Gesture Spreads, a Spirit Long Dormant Is Revived
headline.print_headline: Player’s Protest Revives a Spirit of Activism From the Days of Ali

byline.original: By JOHN ELIGON and SCOTT CACCIOLA
